deck_info.name: Comprehensive Humanities Master Deck
deck_info.description: Complete Humanities deck covering History, Geography, Philosophy, Sociology, and Psychology

history.name: History

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Ancient Egypt
cards.back: Civilization along the Nile River (3100-30 BCE) known for pyramids, pharaohs, hieroglyphics, and mummification.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Ancient Greece
cards.back: Civilization (800-146 BCE) that developed democracy, philosophy, theater, and Olympic Games.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Ancient Rome
cards.back: Empire (753 BCE-476 CE) that built roads, aqueducts, and created a legal system that influenced modern law.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Mesopotamia
cards.back: Region between Tigris and Euphrates rivers where the first cities, writing (cuneiform), and agriculture developed.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Indus Valley
cards.back: Ancient civilization (3300-1300 BCE) in South Asia known for advanced urban planning and drainage systems.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Ancient China
cards.back: Civilization along the Yellow River that developed paper, gunpowder, compass, and printing.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Maya Civilization
cards.back: Mesoamerican civilization (2000 BCE-1500 CE) known for pyramids, calendar system, and hieroglyphic writing.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Aztec Empire
cards.back: Mesoamerican empire (1345-1521) centered in Tenochtitlan, known for human sacrifice and advanced architecture.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Inca Empire
cards.back: South American empire (1438-1533) known for Machu Picchu, road systems, and terrace farming.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Persian Empire
cards.back: Ancient empire (550-330 BCE) that ruled from Egypt to India, known for tolerance and administrative efficiency.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Feudalism
cards.back: Social system where land was exchanged for military service and loyalty to lords.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Crusades
cards.back: Series of religious wars (1095-1291) between Christians and Muslims for control of the Holy Land.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Black Death
cards.back: Plague pandemic (1347-1351) that killed 30-60% of Europe's population.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Magna Carta
cards.back: Document signed in 1215 that limited the power of English kings and established basic rights.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Hundred Years' War
cards.back: Conflict (1337-1453) between England and France over French territory.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Renaissance
cards.back: Period of cultural rebirth (14th-17th centuries) marked by renewed interest in classical learning and art.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Reformation
cards.back: Religious movement (16th century) that led to the creation of Protestant churches.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Age of Exploration
cards.back: Period (15th-17th centuries) when European nations explored and colonized other parts of the world.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Enlightenment
cards.back: Intellectual movement (17th-18th centuries) emphasizing reason, individualism, and skepticism.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Industrial Revolution
cards.back: Period (1760-1840) when manufacturing shifted from hand production to machines.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: French Revolution
cards.back: Period of radical social and political upheaval in France (1789-1799) that overthrew the monarchy.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: American Revolution
cards.back: Colonial revolt (1765-1783) that resulted in United States independence from Great Britain.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Napoleonic Wars
cards.back: Series of conflicts (1803-1815) involving Napoleon Bonaparte's French Empire against various European coalitions.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: American Civil War
cards.back: Conflict (1861-1865) between Northern and Southern states over slavery and states' rights.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: World War I
cards.back: Global conflict (1914-1918) involving most European nations, resulting in millions of casualties.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Russian Revolution
cards.back: Revolution (1917) that overthrew the Russian monarchy and established the Soviet Union.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Great Depression
cards.back: Severe worldwide economic downturn (1929-1939) marked by high unemployment and poverty.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: World War II
cards.back: Global conflict (1939-1945) involving most nations, ending with the use of atomic bombs.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Cold War
cards.back: Period of geopolitical tension (1947-1991) between the United States and Soviet Union.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Civil Rights Movement
cards.back: Social movement (1954-1968) in the United States to end racial segregation and discrimination.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Vietnam War
cards.back: Conflict (1955-1975) between North and South Vietnam, with US involvement.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Fall of Berlin Wall
cards.back: Event (1989) symbolizing the end of the Cold War and division of Germany.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: 9/11 Attacks
cards.back: Terrorist attacks (2001) on the World Trade Center and Pentagon that changed US foreign policy.

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: Arab Spring
cards.back: Series of anti-government protests and uprisings across the Arab world (2010-2012).

cards.front: Explain the historical event/period: COVID-19 Pandemic
cards.back: Global pandemic (2019-present) caused by coronavirus that affected economies and societies worldwide.

history.description: Major historical events, periods, and civilizations

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Plate Tectonics
cards.back: Theory that Earth's outer shell is divided into plates that move over the mantle, causing earthquakes and volcanoes.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Weathering
cards.back: Process of breaking down rocks and minerals on Earth's surface through physical, chemical, or biological means.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Erosion
cards.back: Process of wearing away Earth's surface by water, wind, or ice, creating landforms like valleys and canyons.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Deposition
cards.back: Process of dropping sediments in new locations, building up landforms like deltas and beaches.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Climate Zones
cards.back: Large areas of Earth with similar weather patterns: tropical, temperate, and polar zones.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Biomes
cards.back: Large ecological areas with similar climate, plants, and animals: desert, forest, grassland, tundra, aquatic.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Ecosystems
cards.back: Communities of living organisms interacting with their physical environment.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Water Cycle
cards.back: Continuous movement of water on, above, and below Earth's surface through evaporation, condensation, and precipitation.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Carbon Cycle
cards.back: Movement of carbon between the atmosphere, oceans, soil, and living organisms.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Rock Cycle
cards.back: Process by which rocks change from one type to another through weathering, erosion, and heat/pressure.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Population Density
cards.back: Number of people living in a given area, usually measured as people per square kilometer.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Urbanization
cards.back: Process of population concentration in cities and towns, leading to urban growth and development.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Migration
cards.back: Movement of people from one place to another, either within a country (internal) or between countries (international).

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Cultural Diffusion
cards.back: Spread of cultural beliefs, practices, and ideas from one society to another.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Globalization
cards.back: Process of increasing interconnectedness and interdependence among countries through trade, technology, and culture.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Demographics
cards.back: Statistical characteristics of human populations, including age, gender, income, education, and ethnicity.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Economic Development
cards.back: Process of improving economic well-being and quality of life for a country's population.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Sustainable Development
cards.back: Development that meets present needs without compromising future generations' ability to meet their own needs.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Cultural Landscape
cards.back: Visible features of an area shaped by human activity and culture.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Environmental Impact
cards.back: Effect of human activities on the natural environment, including pollution and habitat destruction.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Continents
cards.back: Seven large landmasses: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Oceans
cards.back: Five major bodies of saltwater: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern, and Arctic.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Mountain Ranges
cards.back: Chains of mountains formed by tectonic activity, including Himalayas, Andes, Rockies, and Alps.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Rivers
cards.back: Natural flowing watercourses that drain into oceans, lakes, or other rivers.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Deserts
cards.back: Arid regions with little precipitation, including Sahara, Arabian, Gobi, and Mojave.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Rainforests
cards.back: Dense forests with high rainfall, including Amazon, Congo, and Southeast Asian rainforests.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Tundra
cards.back: Treeless Arctic regions with permanently frozen subsoil and low-growing vegetation.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Savanna
cards.back: Grassland ecosystems with scattered trees, found in tropical and subtropical regions.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Mediterranean Climate
cards.back: Climate characterized by hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters.

cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Monsoon
cards.back: Seasonal wind pattern that brings heavy rainfall to certain regions, especially South Asia.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Metaphysics
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with the fundamental nature of reality and existence.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Epistemology
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with the nature and scope of knowledge.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Ethics
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with moral principles and values.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Logic
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with valid reasoning and argumentation.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Aesthetics
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with beauty, art, and taste.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Political Philosophy
cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with government, justice, and social organization.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Dualism
cards.back: Belief that mind and body are fundamentally different substances.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Materialism
cards.back: Belief that only matter exists and everything can be explained in material terms.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Idealism
cards.back: Belief that reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual rather than physical.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Empiricism
cards.back: Belief that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience and observation.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Rationalism
cards.back: Belief that knowledge comes primarily from reason and logical thinking.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Skepticism
cards.back: Philosophical position that questions the possibility of certain knowledge.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Relativism
cards.back: Belief that truth and morality are relative to culture, society, or individual perspective.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Absolutism
cards.back: Belief that certain principles are universally true regardless of context.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Utilitarianism
cards.back: Ethical theory that actions are right if they promote the greatest happiness for the greatest number.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Deontology
cards.back: Ethical theory that actions are right or wrong based on their adherence to moral rules or duties.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Socrates
cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (470-399 BCE) known for the Socratic method and questioning approach.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Plato
cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (428-348 BCE) who founded the Academy and wrote philosophical dialogues.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Aristotle
cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (384-322 BCE) who studied logic, ethics, politics, and natural sciences.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Confucius
cards.back: Chinese philosopher (551-479 BCE) whose teachings emphasized moral behavior and social harmony.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Descartes
cards.back: French philosopher (1596-1650) known for 'Cogito, ergo sum' and mind-body dualism.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Kant
cards.back: German philosopher (1724-1804) who developed deontological ethics and transcendental idealism.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Nietzsche
cards.back: German philosopher (1844-1900) known for critiques of morality and the concept of the Übermensch.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Sartre
cards.back: French philosopher (1905-1980) associated with existentialism and human freedom.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Foucault
cards.back: French philosopher (1926-1984) who studied power, knowledge, and social institutions.

cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Chomsky
cards.back: American philosopher (1928-present) known for work on language, politics, and media.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Functionalism
cards.back: Theory that society is a system of interconnected parts that work together to maintain stability.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Conflict Theory
cards.back: Theory that society is characterized by inequality and conflict between different groups.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Symbolic Interactionism
cards.back: Theory that society is created through everyday interactions and shared meanings.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Constructionism
cards.back: Theory that reality is socially constructed through human interaction and language.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Feminist Theory
cards.back: Theory that examines gender inequality and advocates for women's rights and equality.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Critical Race Theory
cards.back: Theory that examines how race and racism are embedded in social structures and institutions.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Family
cards.back: Social institution that provides emotional support, socialization, and economic cooperation.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Education
cards.back: Social institution that transmits knowledge, skills, and cultural values to new generations.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Religion
cards.back: Social institution that provides meaning, purpose, and moral guidance to individuals and communities.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Government
cards.back: Social institution that exercises authority and control over a society.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Economy
cards.back: Social institution that organizes the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Media
cards.back: Social institution that communicates information, entertainment, and cultural content to the public.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Socialization
cards.back: Process by which individuals learn the norms, values, and behaviors of their society.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Stratification
cards.back: System of ranking individuals and groups in a hierarchy based on wealth, power, and prestige.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Mobility
cards.back: Movement of individuals or groups between different social positions.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Deviance
cards.back: Behavior that violates social norms and expectations.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Control
cards.back: Mechanisms used by society to ensure conformity to social norms.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Change
cards.back: Transformation of social institutions, behaviors, and relationships over time.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Poverty
cards.back: Condition of lacking basic material needs and resources for a decent standard of living.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Inequality
cards.back: Unequal distribution of resources, opportunities, and power among different groups.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Discrimination
cards.back: Unfair treatment of individuals or groups based on characteristics like race, gender, or religion.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Movements
cards.back: Organized efforts by groups to bring about social or political change.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Globalization
cards.back: Process of increasing interconnectedness and interdependence among societies worldwide.

cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Environmental Sociology
cards.back: Study of the relationship between society and the natural environment.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Clinical Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies, assesses, and treats people with psychological disorders.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Cognitive Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies mental processes like thinking, memory, and problem-solving.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Developmental Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies how people change and grow throughout their lives.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Social Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by others.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Behavioral Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies observable behavior and learning processes.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Biological Psychology
cards.back: Branch that studies the biological basis of behavior and mental processes.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Consciousness
cards.back: Awareness of one's thoughts, feelings, and surroundings.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Memory
cards.back: Process of encoding, storing, and retrieving information.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Learning
cards.back: Process of acquiring new knowledge, skills, or behaviors.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Motivation
cards.back: Internal and external factors that drive behavior toward goals.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Emotion
cards.back: Complex psychological and physiological state that influences thoughts and behavior.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Personality
cards.back: Enduring patterns of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that characterize an individual.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Intelligence
cards.back: Ability to learn, reason, problem-solve, and adapt to new situations.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Stress
cards.back: Body's response to demands or threats, both real and perceived.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Mental Health
cards.back: State of psychological well-being and ability to function effectively in daily life.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Psychological Disorders
cards.back: Patterns of thoughts, feelings, or behaviors that cause distress or impairment.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Sigmund Freud
cards.back: Austrian neurologist (1856-1939) who founded psychoanalysis and studied the unconscious mind.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: B.F. Skinner
cards.back: American psychologist (1904-1990) who studied operant conditioning and behaviorism.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Jean Piaget
cards.back: Swiss psychologist (1896-1980) who studied cognitive development in children.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Carl Jung
cards.back: Swiss psychiatrist (1875-1961) who developed analytical psychology and studied the collective unconscious.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Abraham Maslow
cards.back: American psychologist (1908-1970) who developed the hierarchy of needs.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Ivan Pavlov
cards.back: Russian physiologist (1849-1936) who studied classical conditioning with dogs.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Erik Erikson
cards.back: German-American psychologist (1902-1994) who developed the theory of psychosocial development.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Albert Bandura
cards.back: Canadian-American psychologist (1925-2021) who studied social learning and self-efficacy.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Lev Vygotsky
cards.back: Russian psychologist (1896-1934) who studied social and cultural influences on development.

cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: William James
cards.back: American psychologist (1842-1910) who founded functionalism and wrote 'Principles of Psychology.'

all_cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Tundra
all_cards.back: Treeless Arctic regions with permanently frozen subsoil and low-growing vegetation.

all_cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Savanna
all_cards.back: Grassland ecosystems with scattered trees, found in tropical and subtropical regions.

all_cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Mediterranean Climate
all_cards.back: Climate characterized by hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters.

all_cards.front: Define the geographical concept: Monsoon
all_cards.back: Seasonal wind pattern that brings heavy rainfall to certain regions, especially South Asia.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Metaphysics
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with the fundamental nature of reality and existence.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Epistemology
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with the nature and scope of knowledge.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Ethics
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with moral principles and values.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Logic
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with valid reasoning and argumentation.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Aesthetics
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with beauty, art, and taste.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Political Philosophy
all_cards.back: Branch of philosophy concerned with government, justice, and social organization.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Dualism
all_cards.back: Belief that mind and body are fundamentally different substances.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Materialism
all_cards.back: Belief that only matter exists and everything can be explained in material terms.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Idealism
all_cards.back: Belief that reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual rather than physical.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Empiricism
all_cards.back: Belief that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience and observation.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Rationalism
all_cards.back: Belief that knowledge comes primarily from reason and logical thinking.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Skepticism
all_cards.back: Philosophical position that questions the possibility of certain knowledge.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Relativism
all_cards.back: Belief that truth and morality are relative to culture, society, or individual perspective.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Absolutism
all_cards.back: Belief that certain principles are universally true regardless of context.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Utilitarianism
all_cards.back: Ethical theory that actions are right if they promote the greatest happiness for the greatest number.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Deontology
all_cards.back: Ethical theory that actions are right or wrong based on their adherence to moral rules or duties.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Socrates
all_cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (470-399 BCE) known for the Socratic method and questioning approach.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Plato
all_cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (428-348 BCE) who founded the Academy and wrote philosophical dialogues.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Aristotle
all_cards.back: Ancient Greek philosopher (384-322 BCE) who studied logic, ethics, politics, and natural sciences.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Confucius
all_cards.back: Chinese philosopher (551-479 BCE) whose teachings emphasized moral behavior and social harmony.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Descartes
all_cards.back: French philosopher (1596-1650) known for 'Cogito, ergo sum' and mind-body dualism.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Kant
all_cards.back: German philosopher (1724-1804) who developed deontological ethics and transcendental idealism.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Nietzsche
all_cards.back: German philosopher (1844-1900) known for critiques of morality and the concept of the Übermensch.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Sartre
all_cards.back: French philosopher (1905-1980) associated with existentialism and human freedom.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Foucault
all_cards.back: French philosopher (1926-1984) who studied power, knowledge, and social institutions.

all_cards.front: Explain the philosophical concept: Chomsky
all_cards.back: American philosopher (1928-present) known for work on language, politics, and media.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Functionalism
all_cards.back: Theory that society is a system of interconnected parts that work together to maintain stability.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Conflict Theory
all_cards.back: Theory that society is characterized by inequality and conflict between different groups.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Symbolic Interactionism
all_cards.back: Theory that society is created through everyday interactions and shared meanings.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Constructionism
all_cards.back: Theory that reality is socially constructed through human interaction and language.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Feminist Theory
all_cards.back: Theory that examines gender inequality and advocates for women's rights and equality.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Critical Race Theory
all_cards.back: Theory that examines how race and racism are embedded in social structures and institutions.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Family
all_cards.back: Social institution that provides emotional support, socialization, and economic cooperation.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Education
all_cards.back: Social institution that transmits knowledge, skills, and cultural values to new generations.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Religion
all_cards.back: Social institution that provides meaning, purpose, and moral guidance to individuals and communities.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Government
all_cards.back: Social institution that exercises authority and control over a society.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Economy
all_cards.back: Social institution that organizes the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Media
all_cards.back: Social institution that communicates information, entertainment, and cultural content to the public.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Socialization
all_cards.back: Process by which individuals learn the norms, values, and behaviors of their society.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Stratification
all_cards.back: System of ranking individuals and groups in a hierarchy based on wealth, power, and prestige.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Mobility
all_cards.back: Movement of individuals or groups between different social positions.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Deviance
all_cards.back: Behavior that violates social norms and expectations.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Control
all_cards.back: Mechanisms used by society to ensure conformity to social norms.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Change
all_cards.back: Transformation of social institutions, behaviors, and relationships over time.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Poverty
all_cards.back: Condition of lacking basic material needs and resources for a decent standard of living.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Inequality
all_cards.back: Unequal distribution of resources, opportunities, and power among different groups.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Discrimination
all_cards.back: Unfair treatment of individuals or groups based on characteristics like race, gender, or religion.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Social Movements
all_cards.back: Organized efforts by groups to bring about social or political change.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Globalization
all_cards.back: Process of increasing interconnectedness and interdependence among societies worldwide.

all_cards.front: Define the sociological concept: Environmental Sociology
all_cards.back: Study of the relationship between society and the natural environment.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Clinical Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies, assesses, and treats people with psychological disorders.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Cognitive Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies mental processes like thinking, memory, and problem-solving.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Developmental Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies how people change and grow throughout their lives.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Social Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by others.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Behavioral Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies observable behavior and learning processes.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Biological Psychology
all_cards.back: Branch that studies the biological basis of behavior and mental processes.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Consciousness
all_cards.back: Awareness of one's thoughts, feelings, and surroundings.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Memory
all_cards.back: Process of encoding, storing, and retrieving information.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Learning
all_cards.back: Process of acquiring new knowledge, skills, or behaviors.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Motivation
all_cards.back: Internal and external factors that drive behavior toward goals.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Emotion
all_cards.back: Complex psychological and physiological state that influences thoughts and behavior.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Personality
all_cards.back: Enduring patterns of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that characterize an individual.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Intelligence
all_cards.back: Ability to learn, reason, problem-solve, and adapt to new situations.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Stress
all_cards.back: Body's response to demands or threats, both real and perceived.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Mental Health
all_cards.back: State of psychological well-being and ability to function effectively in daily life.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Psychological Disorders
all_cards.back: Patterns of thoughts, feelings, or behaviors that cause distress or impairment.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Sigmund Freud
all_cards.back: Austrian neurologist (1856-1939) who founded psychoanalysis and studied the unconscious mind.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: B.F. Skinner
all_cards.back: American psychologist (1904-1990) who studied operant conditioning and behaviorism.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Jean Piaget
all_cards.back: Swiss psychologist (1896-1980) who studied cognitive development in children.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Carl Jung
all_cards.back: Swiss psychiatrist (1875-1961) who developed analytical psychology and studied the collective unconscious.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Abraham Maslow
all_cards.back: American psychologist (1908-1970) who developed the hierarchy of needs.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Ivan Pavlov
all_cards.back: Russian physiologist (1849-1936) who studied classical conditioning with dogs.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Erik Erikson
all_cards.back: German-American psychologist (1902-1994) who developed the theory of psychosocial development.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Albert Bandura
all_cards.back: Canadian-American psychologist (1925-2021) who studied social learning and self-efficacy.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: Lev Vygotsky
all_cards.back: Russian psychologist (1896-1934) who studied social and cultural influences on development.

all_cards.front: Explain the psychological concept: William James
all_cards.back: American psychologist (1842-1910) who founded functionalism and wrote 'Principles of Psychology.'
